dir-section.heading: The Federal Judicial System
dir-section.p: The Supreme Court is the ultimate court of appeal in both civil and criminal cases throughout Canada. The Court is also required to advise on questions referred to it by the Governor-General in Council. Questions concerning the interpretation of the Constitution Act, the constitutionality or interpretation of any federal or provincial law, the powers of Parliament or of the provincial legislatures, among other matters, may be referred by the Government to the Supreme Court for consideration. There are nine Supreme Court judges, including the Chief Justice of Canada, and at least five judges are required to be present for a case to be heard (although it is normal for the full Court to sit in most instances). The judges are appointed by the Governor in Council and hold office until reaching the age of 75 years. Judges may only be removed from office by the Governor-General on address of the federal Senate and House of Commons.

address.verbatim-address: Supreme Court Bldg, 301 Wellington St, Ottawa, ON K1A 0J1

dir-section.p: The Federal Court has jurisdiction in claims against the Crown, claims by the Crown, miscellaneous cases involving the Crown and its officers and servants, relief (including judicial review) against federal boards, commissions and other tribunals, jurisdiction over interprovincial and federal-provincial disputes, income tax and estate tax appeals, industrial or intellectual property matters, maritime and admiralty matters, citizenship appeals, aeronautics and interprovincial works and undertakings. The Court has residuary jurisdiction for relief if there is no other court that has such jurisdiction, and jurisdiction in specific matters conferred by federal statutes. It is composed of 35 full-time judges, a number of supernumerary judges (semi-retired, part-time judges) and a chief justice who are appointed by the Governor in Council.

address.verbatim-address: Supreme Court Bldg, Kent and Wellington Sts, Ottawa, ON K1A 0H9

dir-section.p: The Federal Court of Appeal has jurisdiction on appeals from the Trial Division, appeals from Federal Tribunals, review of decisions of Federal Boards and Commissions, appeals from Tribunals and Reviews under Section 28 of the Federal Court Act, and references by Federal Boards and Commissions. The Court comprises a chief justice and 12 judges (appointed by the Governor in Council).

address.verbatim-address:
Thomas D’Arcy McGee Bldg, 90 Sparks St, Main Floor, Ottawa, ON
K1A 0H9

org-entry.content-note: the Court has one central registry and consists of principal office in Ottawa and local offices in major centres throughout Canada

dir-entry.dir-entry-name: Chief Justice, Federal Court of Appeal

dir-section.heading: Federal Judicial Bodies with Specific Purposes
dir-section.p: The Court Martial Appeal Court of Canada was established in 1959. The Court has jurisdiction over appeals from the Courts Martial. Established under the National Defence Act, the Courts Martial are military courts that have jurisdiction over military personnel and civilians accompanying them abroad, for crimes and offences against the Code of Service Discipline.

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Court Martial Appeal Court of Canada

address.verbatim-address: Thomas D'Arcy McGee Bldg, 90 Sparks St, Ottawa, ON K1A 0H9

dir-section.p: The Tax Court of Canada has jurisdiction over appeals concerning the Income Tax Act, the Canada Pension Plan, the Old Age Security Act, the Petroleum and Gas Revenue Tax Act, the Employment Insurance Act and Part IX of the Excise Tax Act for the Goods and Services Tax. The Court also has jurisdiction to hear and determine appeals on matters arising under the War Veterans Allowance Act and the Merchant Navy and Civilian War-related Benefits Act. Hearings may be held in major centres throughout the country for income tax appeals and in smaller communities for appeals relating to unemployment insurance. The Federal Court of Canada may hear appeals of Tax Court decisions.

The Courts Administration Service (CAS) was established in 2003 as a result of the consolidation of the former registries of the Federal Court of Canada and of the Tax Court of Canada under the 2002 Courts Administration Service Act. The CAS provides administrative services to the Federal Court of Appeal, the Federal Court, the Court Martial Appeal Court of Canada and the Tax Court of Canada. The service aims to increase financial transparency and to ensure judicial independence. The CAS is represented by 17 registry offices across the provinces and territories.

address.verbatim-address: Supreme Court Bldg, Kent and Wellington Sts, Ottawa, ON K1A 0H9

dir-section.p: The Social Security Tribunal is responsible for hearing appeals arising from the decisions of the review tribunals under the Employment Insurance, Canada Pension Plan, and Old Age Security decisions since April 2013, which were formerly handled by the Pension Appeals Board. Appeals are heard in all provinces and territories and the findings of the board are sent to all parties connected with the appeal.

address.verbatim-address:
POB 9812, Station T CSC, Otta
wa, ON K1G 6S3

dir-section.p: The Office of the Commissioner for Federal Judicial Affairs is responsible for administrative matters relating to the Federal Court of Canada, the Tax Court of Canada, the Canadian Judicial Council and all federally appointed judges, with the exception of those of the Supreme Court of Canada.

org-entry-head.org-entry-name: Office of the Commissioner for Federal Judicial Affairs

address.verbatim-address: 99 Metcalfe St, 8th Floor, Ottawa, ON K1A 1E3
